How a Block is created and linked into the Blockchain, in Hyperledger Fabric ?

In bitcoin,
1. A certain no. of txns constitute a Block  [ Block => Block no. + Previous Block's Hash + Txns + x(sealing no., a puzzle need to solve in Minning process) 
In Minning,

How a Block is created and linked into the Blockchain, in Hyperledger Fabric ?

In bitcoin,
1. A fixed no. of txns constitute a Block 
         [ Block => Block no. + Previous Block's Hash + Txns + x(sealing no., a puzzle need to solve in Minning process) 
2. Minning is done to solve the puzzle , and to Seal the Block  [ time taken : 10mins approx ]
3. After this, all peers verify the Sealed Block (i.e., Minning process)
4. This Sealed Block gets appended to the Blockchain
In this way, Block Creation is done; Proof of Work Consensus Algorithm is applied; And finally, Block gets chained to the Blockchain

How this works in Hyperledger Fabric ? [Note: I have gone through the Txn Flow of Hyperledger Fabric, but could not find these]
[1-3]Block creation related
1. How a Block is created ?
2. Block has only 1 txn ? (if no, how we can use this in IOT then, where instant response is the need, i.e., highly efficient protocol)
3. Block has fixed no. of txns ? 
[4-6 related to Consensus Algo]
4. How Consensus Algorithm works (even at the time of malicious entities) 
5. What if endorsers cheats? 
6. What if 51% of the peers of a channel are malicious ?
[7-8 Hashing & Sealing of Block]
7. Are we using similar Sealing of Blocks(Minning)? Solving puzzles or Simple Hashing is applied ??
8. How efficient is Hyperledger Fabric, in terms of validating a brand new Transaction ?
(from txn proposal to txn being appended to the Blockchain )
[Security]
9.As, Solving a puzzle in Bitcoin Blockchain is making the system Computationally-Secure, so that malicious parties(having <51% network's computational power) can't break it.
How secure is Hyperledger Fabric ??

@UtkarshSingh look up the Kafka based ordering service for hyperledger fabric. The block size is determined by the rate of transactions to a max size or a batch timer. With this a block could have 1 txn or a size you specify (if the size isnt met by the batch timer the block wont be full)

@UtkarshSingh Additionally bitcoin and etherium are both permission-less block chains meaning anyone can jump on and start. With hyper-ledger fabric the blockchain is permissioned so the peers will need to be verified before allowing them access to the blockchain. Look at hyperledger as more of a business solution rather than an open thing anyone can jump on.

Has joined the channel.

@glotov the data_hash is hash of transactions in this block , the previous_hash is hash of all data in previous block. Actually a block can not have its own hash in it, because before hash you need to know all data of the block include the hash.

Take a look at the : http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/fabric_model.html#chaincode

To further obfuscate the data, values within chaincode can be encrypted (in part or in total) using common cryptographic algorithms such as AES before sending transactions to the ordering service and appending blocks to the ledger. Once encrypted data has been written to the ledger, it can only be decrypted by a user in possession of the corresponding key that was used to generate the cipher text. For further details on chaincode encryption, see the Chaincode for Developers topic.

Hello everyone i found a bug when setting the postgreSQL database host different than localhost: ```
`const connectionString = 'postgres://' + pgconfig.username + ':' + pgconfig.passwd + '@localhost:' + pgconfig.port + '/' + pgconfig.database;`
```
at app/db/pgservice.js
it ignores the config.json pg host database
it should be
`const connectionString = 'postgres://' + pgconfig.username + ':' + pgconfig.passwd + '@' + pgconfig.host + ':' + pgconfig.port + '/' + pgconfig.database;`

npm install
npm run build

ok - got a quick run-down from a ReactJS guy - running npm start in the client runs the front-end part in development mode. You get useful stack traces and error reporting in the browser. Building the Explorer in "production" mode requires you to do the "npm run build" in /client which will generate the static files that then get statically linked-to by the web-app part (the node main.js in the blockchain-explorer parent directory) - this hides any useful error messages
so, if you make a change to any of the code under /client, then you will either need to do a "npm start" or "npm run build"

@header340 ok so if you are hitting http://localhost:8080 correctly,  the error (Cannot read property 'foreach' in headerview.js) suggests the channel list is empty. And without a channel name, the app cannot fetch any data and hence the white screen. If the API call to get counts works, it cannot be a network connectivity issue, check config.json as for initial setup explorer reads from config file. Also Is your explorer code from release-3.1 branch or release-3.2 branch or master. If your network is fabric version 1.1.0, you need release-3.2. If your fabric network  is 1.0, explorer version 0.3.0 from master will work fine for you. If you originally had fabric 1.0 and want to migrate to 1.1.0, fabric provides an upgrade guide and then you can checkout explorer from release-3.2 branch and build. Besides that if you ran npm install in the blockchain-explorer directory and then again in client directory and ran 'npm run build' in client directory before starting up app, it should be good. What happens if instead of using the start script, you run 'node main.js' in the block-chain-explorer directory.

@vanitas92 I met the same issue before.  You can try to modify the updatepg.sql file your self and make these columns longer and then re-setup the database

```
ALTER TABLE Transaction ADD COLUMN validation_code character varying(50) DEFAULT NULL,
ADD COLUMN envelope_signature character varying(2000) DEFAULT NULL,
ADD COLUMN payload_extension character varying(2000) DEFAULT NULL,
ADD COLUMN creator_id_bytes character varying(2000) DEFAULT NULL,
ADD COLUMN creator_nonce character varying(2000) DEFAULT NULL,
```
I made all the columns with the length 2000

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=ZHAHAYpnB4z7pNH7w) @RealDeanZhao Thank you. I though the same and i was trying to figure out which column was by checking the logs of postgresql

I was thinking the reason of limiting the character types in these columns. A quick consult in the following official documentation link: [https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.0/static/datatype-character.html](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.0/static/datatype-character.html) says that if you do not specify the varying(n) then the database accepts strings of any size. Moreover, there is no performance issue.

Hi all just wanted to share a solution to a problem I was having....I followed the Hyperledger Tutorial here: https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer
I tried for many hours to get it working, but every time I would navigate to local host I would simply get a blank screen.  To find out what the problem was I went to the logs folder and realised that the config.json file did not accurately reflect my directory structure....basically the file path was wrong!  I fixed it and it worked.  The reason Im sharing this is because Im sure there are many people who are beginners and perhaps need the help..

OK got it
This is because of Git Bash appending ";C" when converting Windows paths
Adding a leading "/" before `$network_config_file` and `$network_crypto_base_path` in the _deploy_explorer.sh_ file did the trick
Adding a leading "/" before `$network_config_file` and `$network_crypto_base_path` in the _deploy\_explorer.sh_ file did the trick
Adding a leading "/" before `$network_config_file` and `$network_crypto_base_path` in the deploy_explorer.sh file did the trick
Adding a leading "/" before `$network_config_file` and `$network_crypto_base_path` in the `deploy_explorer.sh` file did the trick
Credits : https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50608301/docker-mounted-volume-adds-c-to-end-of-windows-path-when-translating-from-linux

@nfrunza I finally got it to work by :
- removing network creation [deploy_explorer.sh]
- replacing network name with the existing one running my fabric installation [deploy_explorer.sh]
- removing `--ip` parameters when running db and explorer containers [deploy_explorer.sh]

So all containers run in the same network, then I had to :
- replace `db_ip` with the one got from the db container IP in the existing network (`docker network inspect mynetwork`) [deploy_explorer.sh]
- replacing 127.0.0.1 by service name [config.json]

Just a note for others having trouble getting explorer running under docker. It wasn't working for me and in the app.log was seeing this error:
[2018-08-28 08:27:25.019] [ERROR] Query - TypeError: Cannot read property 'queryChannels' of undefined

    at Platform.initialize (/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/Platform.js:155:16)
    at Function.build (/opt/explorer/app/platform/PlatformBuilder.js:11:22)
    at platformroutes (/opt/explorer/app/explorer/rest/platformroutes.js:14:36)
    at Explorer.initialize (/opt/explorer/app/explorer/Explorer.js:40:13)
    at <anonymous>
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:188:7)
Some digging around the code, in configuration.js, 	found that it expects the org sections defined under network-config in config.json to contain the string "org". My original config, yielding above error, was similar to this:
	{
	"network-config": {
		"myCompany": {
			"name": "myCompany",
			"mspid": "myCompanyMSP",
			"peer1": ...
			
changing config.json to look like the example below resolved the issue
	{
	"network-config": {
		"orgMyCompany": {
			"name": "myCompany",
			"mspid": "myCompanyMSP",
			"peer1": ...

I finally figured out the issue so I thought I would share in case anyone else is having similar issues.  My issue was that I could see transactions occurring in the database for explorer, however, upon trying to go to localhost:8080, it would stay on the loading page indefinitely.  The issue ended up being that the channel name that I thought was correct in the config file was incorrect. @vanitas92  Short answer...it took a while ;) Longer answer, we were moving from a 0.35 fabric 1.1 setup...and the key gotcha for me was that the config.json structure completely changed...so my advice is to go through that with a fine tooth comb and make sure all the mspids, keys, certs, urls, etc are exactly correct for YOUR network. No point in posting mine because its for out fabric network which is not standard. Use https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/config.json as a starting point...this is the correct format. As for how we achieved connection over https...we are running our network on kubenetes and used a TLS ingress. However, sounds to me like your issue is something not matching your network within the config.json - but I'm not an expert in this!

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=guFA4nM8b5Bh6iFLo) @vanitas92 I'm also unclear on the "clients" section so if anyone on here has definitive answer please jump in. My guess is it is related to the NodeSDK client config see here :https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/tutorial-network-config.html. The error you are seeing comes from here: https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/FabricClient.js line 116. I also had this error at one point. Reading the code, the first thing it does with fabric client after initialization is call queryChannels and if that returns empty...you get this error. So, either there are no channels on your network or, more likely, the config is wrong somehow and its not able to connect.  I would suggest this...take the url to the peer you are connecting to (the one matching organization in the clients section) then remote on to your explorer pod and try a cmd like this: nc -zv {{your_hostname_or_ip_from_url_property}} {{port_from_url}}  If this doesn't return open then you have some sort of network issue or your config is wrong. Other things to check that the certs and keys in your config.json are actually there. Sorry can't be of more help but I'm no expert...just hacking my way.

Requests from many developers to be able to run HLExplorer with fabric-ca server. 


1) Use fabric-ca client and admin credentials to login to fabric-ca server. 
2) Enroll HLExplorer user to fabric-ca, and store the generated user credentials in a temp directory, can be under explorer 
3) Verify if user exists on the CA, if they do not, register them. 
4) Verify if user exists credentials (key/cert pair) exist before enrolling, and that credentials are valid, otherwise re-enroll the HLExplorer user. 
5) Minimize or avoid using CDM tools for generating credentials or enroll HLExplorer user, we want as less as possible use of command tools. 

Balance transfer sample has a fabric-ca server, https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/master/balance-transfer#sample-rest-apis-requests , and can be used top test explorer 



Some suggestions how to achieve this : 

Suppose you launch root ca (localhost:7054) and intermediate ca (localhost:8054) on localhost. 
Firstly, you should register identity with hf.IntermediateCA=true attribute by root ca. For example: 

fabric-ca-client register --id.name ica --id.attrs '"hf.Registrar.Roles=user,peer",hf.Revoker=true,hf.IntermediateCA=true' --id.secret icapw 
Secondly, open intermediate ca home directory and initialize the intermediate ca: 
fabric-ca-server init -b icaadmin:icaadminpw -u http://ica:icapw@localhost:7054 
Change port of intermediate ca (8054) and some other settings of intermediate ca in fabric-ca-server-config.yaml file. 

After that, you can start intermediate ca: 

fabric-ca-server start
```

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=zB2mxdK9CTmsCCEXY) Hyperledger Composer Setup :
1.  npm install -g composer-cli
2.  npm install -g composer-rest-server
3.  npm install -g generator-hyperledger-composer
4.  npm install -g yo
5.  npm install -g composer-playground
6.  mkdir ~/fabric-tools && cd ~/fabric-tools
7.  curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/hyperledger/composer-tools/master/packages/fabric-dev-servers/fabric-dev-servers.tar.gz
8.  tar -xvf fabric-dev-servers.tar.gz
If based on your use case you can export Fabric version in below example
Fabric 1.1
cd ~/fabric-tools
export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv11
./downloadFabric.sh

Fabric 1.2

cd ~/fabric-tools
export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv12
./downloadFabric.sh
Start the Hyperledger Fabric based on version
 
Fabric 1.1
    cd ~/fabric-tools
    export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv11
    ./startFabric.sh
    ./createPeerAdminCard.sh
Fabric 1.2
cd ~/fabric-tools
    export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv12
    ./startFabric.sh
    ./createPeerAdminCard.sh

  - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP=peer0.org1.example.com:7051

after that i cleared all running containers and started fresh from scratch.

@titoe218 Are you sure that you're connecting to the right endpoints? Furthermore, make sure that there is a long enough delay between starting the peers and trying to connect to them. I've run into issues in the past with that.

Gotcha, do you have TLS properly enabled? If not, then you're going to want to change the grpcs to grpc. Furthermore, look in your docker-compose.yml file to find the endpoints. You should have something that resembles this in some way: 

```
 peer0.org1.example.com:
    container_name: peer0.org1.example.com
    extends:
      file: peer-base/peer-base.yaml
      service: peer-base
    environment:
      - CORE_PEER_ID=peer0.org1.example.com
      - CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=peer0.org1.example.com:7051
      - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051
#      - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_ORGLEADER=true
      - CORE_PEER_LOCALMSPID=Org1MSP
    volumes:
      - /var/run/:/host/var/run/
      - ./e2e-2Orgs/${CONFIG_FOLDER}/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/peers/peer0.org1.example.com/:/etc/hyperledger/msp/peer:ro
    ports:
      - 7051:7051
      - 7053:7053
    depends_on:
      - orderer.example.com
```

You can see that the address is peer0.org1.example.com:7051, so your URL should be ok, as long as your ports are correct.

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=htgfCN4M5EgmrCXgw) @junki Depends what you mean by "information". The initial configuration is done via the config.json file which you have to supply. When a transaction occurs, it is stored in the database. Is it reading the database and printing it to the Web?

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=4veZiT67qCsQXKHgD) @junki Fabric stores transactions/blocks in internal fabric DB(levelDB, or couchDB depending how you start your fabric), Explorer queries block/transactions from fabric and stores in local postgreSQL DB that is in sync with fabric, so it would not query fabric every time you need to preview, search blocks or transactions

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=7aEDYjk6T8qT8A5Jv) #### Possible cause:
    peer node default can't access from out of fabric network
#### Possible solution:
     add environment CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT for peer services, For exampleï¼š
    
    peer0.org1.example.com:
    container_name: peer0.org1.example.com
    image: hyperledger/fabric-peer
    environment:
      - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///host/var/run/docker.sock
      - CORE_PEER_ID=peer0.org1.example.com
      - CORE_LOGGING_PEER=info
      - CORE_CHAINCODE_LOGGING_LEVEL=info
      - CORE_PEER_LOCALMSPID=Org1MSP
      - CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/etc/hyperledger/msp/peer/
      - CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=peer0.org1.example.com:7051
      - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051
 #### Related Information:
    HL Explorer support for HL Fabric 1.3

Does somebody know why in hyperledger explorer peers are shown as "down" but are actual running? And why not alle peers are listed  but the node-counter is correct?

Edit: The reason is the container blockchain-explorer cant reach/ping the peers which are listed as down. (You can see it with the command docker exec -ti blockchain-explorer ping peer1.org1.example.com). Solution is as follows : Insert in Line 194 in deploy-explorer.sh "--add-host=peer1.org1.example.com:ipaddressO

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=QRMFv9SYzEtbNTktA) Does somebody know why in hyperledger explorer peers are shown as "down" but are actual running? And why not alle peers are listed  but the node-counter is correct?

Edit: The reason is the container blockchain-explorer cant reach/ping the peers which are listed as down. (You can see it with the command docker exec -ti blockchain-explorer ping peer1.org1.example.com). Solution is as follows : Insert in Line 194 in deploy-explorer.sh "--add-host=peer1.org1.example.com:ipaddress" . You can do it multiple times, for each down-listed peer. This was also the solution for the non-listed peers.

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=25JKA4DfJTConsugu) @yousaf Yes. we are fetching data from fabric database and storing data in postgreSQL. From postgresSQL we are displaying data in Hyperledger explorer.

HL Explorer Git tags:
v0.3.1 Hyperledger Explorer works with Hyperledger Fabric 1.0.
v0.3.2 - to V0.3.5.1 Hyperledger Explorer works with Hyperledger Fabric 1.1
v0.3.6 Hyperledger Explorer works with Hyperledger Fabric 1.2

$git checkout 'tag you need to use'

$ cd blockchain-explorer/
Edit crypto config blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
$ cd app/persistence/fabric/postgreSQL/db/ && ./createdb.sh
$ nom install
$ cd client/
$ npm install && nom run build && cd ..
$ ./start.sh

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=BFsJ5DFdWDen5GjqT) @nfrunza I figured out how to configure it properly. Turns out I needed to put both the root and intermediate certificates into the .crt file referenced in the tlsCACerts in the config.json, like this:
`-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
// Intermediate CA certificate
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
// Root CA certificate
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
`
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=TPgn4nrrDEBpf7jjY) @ftfnunes i'm glad it worked, i think this is a workaround
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=LTZtRXkkwceE6LxnQ) @nfrunza thanks. i understood.

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=isF3ikJjgHBrtyuE4) @AlbertCL Thanks. It seems to happen when organization name("Org1") is different from mspid ("Org1MSP") at "organizations" section in config.json.

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=isF3ikJjgHBrtyuE4) @AlbertCL Thanks. It seems to happen when organization name("Org1") is different from mspid ("Org1MSP") at "organizations" section in config.json. We'll handle it in a new JIRA.
And for the DeprecationWarning from node.js, we might need to think about doing [this kind of work](https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-942).

orderer0.example.com:
    container_name: orderer0.example.com
    image: hyperledger/fabric-orderer:$IMAGE_TAG
    environment:
      - FABRIC_LOGGING_SPEC=INFO
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_LISTENADDRESS=0.0.0.0
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_GENESISMETHOD=file
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_GENESISFILE=/var/hyperledger/orderer/orderer.genesis.block
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_LOCALMSPID=OrdererMSP
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_LOCALMSPDIR=/var/hyperledger/orderer/msp
      # enabled TLS
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_ENABLED=false
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_PRIVATEKEY=/var/hyperledger/orderer/tls/server.key
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_CERTIFICATE=/var/hyperledger/orderer/tls/server.crt
      - ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_ROOTCAS=[/var/hyperledger/orderer/tls/ca.crt]
    working_dir: /opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric
    command: orderer
    volumes:
    - ../channel-artifacts/genesis.block:/var/hyperledger/orderer/orderer.genesis.block
    - ../crypto-config/ordererOrganizations/example.com/orderers/orderer0.example.com/msp:/var/hyperledger/orderer/msp
    - ../crypto-config/ordererOrganizations/example.com/orderers/orderer0.example.com/tls/:/var/hyperledger/orderer/tls
    - orderer0.example.com:/var/hyperledger/production/orderer
    ports:
      - 22050:7050

volumes:

  credentialstore:

networks:

    external:
      name: artifacts_default

services:

I've added the patch and seems it works normal now on loosing db connection (crossed fingers) ;)

````
---
 app/persistence/postgreSQL/PgService.js | 2 +-
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+), 1 deletion(-)

diff --git a/app/persistence/postgreSQL/PgService.js b/app/persistence/postgreSQL/PgService.js
index 8b49cae..d08de54 100644
--- a/app/persistence/postgreSQL/PgService.js
+++ b/app/persistence/postgreSQL/PgService.js
@@ -67,7 +67,7 @@ class PgService {
 		try {
 			this.client.on('error', err => {
 				console.log('db error', err);
-				if (err.code === 'PROTOCOL_CONNECTION_LOST') {
+				if (err.code === 'PROTOCOL_CONNECTION_LOST' || err.code === 'EPIPE') {
 					this.handleDisconnect();
 				} else {
 					throw err;
-- 
````

EAI_AGAIN means [A temporary failure in name resolution occurred](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-au/windows/win32/api/ws2tcpip/nf-ws2tcpip-getaddrinfo#return-value).
As mentioned on the article ( and also README.md ), you need to align the network that explorer belongs to the one that fabric network belong.
You should be able to see peer containers and explorer containers when inspecting the network ( `docker network inspect {network_name}` ).

The problem was the conf file
In the app/platform/fabric/connection-profile/first-network.json that come by default in the peers : {peer0.org1.example.com {}} key

I think, it's good option that you try to use explorer on first-network first. You need to check the following
* You can see `Error: listen EADDRINUSE :::8080`. Is there any explorer that has already been running?
* If first-network is running on the same machine on which you're trying to start explorer, you need to use `start.sh` or define `export DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=true` for mapping each URL of nodes to localhost.

Maybe you actually want to connect with a password, not Ident. Edit the pg_hba.conf file
host all all 127.0.0.1/32 ident
to

host all all 127.0.0.1/32 md5

Hi! I am experiencing a strange behaviour. I have set the enableAuthentication to false in my connection-profile but the login page is still displayed. The weird thing is that no matter what credentials I enter I am successfully logged in as the server part knows to skip authentication but the client side is still displaying the login page... Does anyone know what might be the issue here?

I have looked at the code and to me it seems that enableAuthenitcation: false is not really doing what I would expect it to. I can see that all /api/* routes are protected with the auth-check middleware which requires that the request have a valid JWT token, which is generated at login. Also if there is no token in the localStorage, the client will automatically redirect itself to /login.

So am I missing something here or doesn't "enableAuthenitcation: false" work? If it works what is its functionality if not skipping the whole authenication process?

**docker-compose.yaml**
```
version: '3.7'

volumes:
  pgdata:
  walletstore:

networks:
  testchain-network:
    external: true
    name: testchain-network

services:

  explorerdb:
    deploy:
      replicas: 1
      restart_policy:
        condition: on-failure
        delay: 5s
        max_attempts: 5
      placement:
        constraints:
          - node.hostname == gcloud1
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '0.50'
          memory: 100M
        reservations:
          cpus: '0.25'
          memory: 50M

    image: hyperledger/explorer-db:1.0.0-rc2
    hostname: explorerdb
    environment:
      - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWORD=password
    volumes:
      - /home/delta/GoWorkspace/src/github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/app/persistence/fabric/postgreSQL/db/createdb.sh:/docker-entrypoint-initdb.d/createdb.sh
      - pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    networks:
      testchain-network:
        aliases:
          - explorerdb

  explorer:
    deploy:
      replicas: 1
      restart_policy:
        condition: on-failure
        delay: 5s
        max_attempts: 5
      placement:
        constraints:
          - node.hostname == gcloud1
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '0.50'
          memory: 100M
        reservations:
          cpus: '0.25'
          memory: 50M

    image: hyperledger/explorer:1.0.0-rc2
    hostname: explorer
    environment:
      - DATABASE_HOST=explorerdb
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWD=password
        # - DATABASE_PORT=5433
      - DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false
    volumes:
      - /home/delta/GoWorkspace/src/github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
      - /home/delta/GoWorkspace/src/github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile
      - /home/delta/GoWorkspace/src/github.com/testchain/networks/crypto-config:/tmp/crypto
      - walletstore:/opt/wallet
    command: sh -c "sleep 16&& node /opt/explorer/main.js && tail -f /dev/null"
    ports:
      - published: 8090
        target: 8080
        mode: host

    networks:
      testchain-network:
        aliases:
          - explorer

    depends_on:
      - explorerdb
```

I guess you are running both fabric network and explorer on same machine. You need to make explorer container join to same network with fabric network. You can specify the network in your docker-compose.yaml.
https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/docker-compose.yaml#L14
And also you need to rephrase all URLs in your connection profile from localhost:* to actual hostname which valid within the docker network. @ravinayag

@sam94 Which version of explorer are you using? We tested connectivity of Explorer with mutual TLS before and  it worked at that time.

Log of the test is below
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-568
> The important configuration is adding not only msp/tlscacerts but also ca cert which is referred by fabric-ca (org*.example.com/ca/ca.org*.example.com-cert.pem) to TLS_CLIENTROOTCAS_FILES.
We didn't need any changes to Explorer, you only need to setup your fabric network appropriately for mutual TLS

Probably gateway class of fabric-sdk-node is in charge of calling setTlsClientCertAndKey(). So user of SDK might only need to set clientTlsIdentity to option when connecting gateway.

## New Features

* Publish new simple landing page on Github
  * Add another README for detail of each configuration
* Add configuration for mutual TLS support
* Add PEM string format support for connection profile
* Add Fabric CA support to retrieve credential for admin access to fabric network

* Fix an issue the targets of discovery service are always mapped to localhost
* Fix calculation of block hash

Hi everyone. Is there a way to run hyperledger-explorer without the private key of org admin? Hyperledger-explorer provides the feature of `Monitoring multiple organizations`(https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#monitoring-multiple-organizations). If the connection profiles of every org require the adminPrivateKeys all admin credential would be stored at a single place which I want to avoid. 
How do you asses the security risk of the overall hyperledger fabric network when running hyperledger-explorer with multiple organizations?
Hi everyone. Is there a way to run hyperledger-explorer without private key of org admin?
@RobinKlemens take a look at minifabric which sets up everything easily including using explorer.

The idea is that each org manages their own nodes. In a real production env, I do not think two orgs will share one machine for things and will share their admin/private keys. Each org will hold their own keys. Explorer user from one org should only be able to use their own admin key to see what is on the network.

You see the cases that multiple orgs have keys on the single machine due to these setups are all test env or dev env. Real production env would not have multiple org peers or orderers running on one machine, these keys will not be altogether neither.

Thanks for your response @tongli .  Alright, I agree to the point that in production env every org would host there own infrastructure. For sure the peers and orderer and hyperledger-explorer instances as well.
Still, the private key of an admin is required. As far as I understand hyperledger-explorer it uses service discovery to retrieve information of the network. But wouldn't a private key of a client be enough (e.g. explorer client with affiliations such as org1.explorer)? I don't want to store the private key of the admin in the explorer container.

@RobinKlemens I am not an explorer expert, but when I added explorer to minifabric, I remember you just need to configure the container to use the private key. Do not think explorer expose the private key any where,  but in any case, since explorer use the key in theory, you will have to secure the explorer itself.
We're using a wallet to store an identity (certificate and private key) on a machine where Explorer is running.
If using HSM wallet and providing a pin to access the HSM from a secret artifactory, it might be more secure.
In this case we also need using Fabric-CA to retrieve an admin identity for avoiding to pass a plain private key to Explorer.

version: '2'
volumes:
  pgdata: null
  walletstore: null
networks:
  my-network_byfn:
    external:
      name: my-network_byfn
services:
  explorerdb.triterras.com:
    image: hyperledger/explorer-db
    container_name: explorerdb.triterras.com
    hostname: explorerdb.triterras.com
    environment:
      - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWORD=password
    volumes:
      - 'pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data'
    networks:
      - my-network_byfn
  explorer.triterras.com:
    image: hyperledger/explorer
    container_name: explorer.triterras.com
    hostname: explorer.triterras.com
    environment:
      - DATABASE_HOST=explorerdb.triterras.com
      - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWD=password
      - LOG_LEVEL_APP=debug
      - LOG_LEVEL_DB=debug
      - LOG_LEVEL_CONSOLE=info
      - LOG_CONSOLE_STDOUT=true
      - DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false
    volumes:
      - './config1.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json'
      - >-
        ./connection-profile:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile/
      - './crypto-config:/tmp/crypto'
    command: sh -c "node /opt/explorer/main.js && tail -f /dev/null"
    ports:
      - '8081:8081'
    depends_on:
      - explorerdb.triterras.com
    networks:
      - my-network_byfn

So I'm not sure of the best way to communicate this, but I've found an oddity with the transaction timestamps in the code of SyncService.js. It seems that the timestamp of the first transaction in the block is assigned to **all** transactions in that block. In l.486 the block timestamp is defined as the timestamp of the first tx in the block, and thereafter this variable is reused for **every tx** in the for loop starting in l. 503. It is finally committed to the database in l.631. However, each transaction actually has a unique timestamp that differs based on when it was created. See the following example for block 177 in my test blockchain, which was created by adding some logging output to SyncService.js: 

``
177
2020-09-15T12:22:28.863Z
2020-09-15T12:22:28.935Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.000Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.069Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.631Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.708Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.796Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.873Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.948Z
2020-09-15T12:22:30.023Z

So I'm not sure of the best way to communicate this, but I've found an oddity with the transaction timestamps in the code of SyncService.js. It seems that the timestamp of the first transaction in the block is assigned to **all** transactions in that block. In l.486 the block timestamp is defined as the timestamp of the first tx in the block, and thereafter this variable is reused for **every tx** in the for loop starting in l. 503. It is finally committed to the database in l.631. However, each transaction actually has a unique timestamp that differs based on when it was created. See the following example for block 177 in my test blockchain, which was created by adding some logging output to SyncService.js: 

```
177
2020-09-15T12:22:28.863Z
2020-09-15T12:22:28.935Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.000Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.069Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.631Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.708Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.796Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.873Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.948Z
2020-09-15T12:22:30.023Z
```

So I'm not sure of the best way to communicate this, but I've found an oddity with the transaction timestamps in the code of SyncService.js. It seems that the timestamp of the first transaction in the block is assigned to **all** transactions in that block. In l.486 the block timestamp is defined as the timestamp of the first tx in the block, and thereafter this variable is reused for **every tx** in the for loop starting in l. 503. It is finally committed to the database in l.631. However, each transaction actually has a unique timestamp that differs based on when it was created. See the following example for block 177 in my test blockchain, which was created by adding some logging output to SyncService.js after modifying it to include the correct timestamps - previously the timestamps would all be equal to the first: 

```
177
2020-09-15T12:22:28.863Z
2020-09-15T12:22:28.935Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.000Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.069Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.631Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.708Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.796Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.873Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.948Z
2020-09-15T12:22:30.023Z
```

Explorer assumes that all peers are running as container on guest OS when `DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST` is set to `true` and `localhost` is assigned across all peers.
Explorer assumes that all peers are running as container on local Docker host when `DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST` is set to `true` and `localhost` is assigned across all peers.

Explorer assumes that all peers are running as container on local Docker host when `DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST` is set to `true` and `localhost` is assigned across all peers as `fabric-samples/test-network` is.

Docker_Compose file

version: '2.1'

volumes:
  pgdata:
  walletstore:

networks:
  mynetwork.com:
    external:
      name: fabric

services:

  explorerdb.mynetwork.com:
    image: hyperledger/explorer-db:latest
    container_name: explorerdb.mynetwork.com
    hostname: explorerdb.mynetwork.com
    environment:
      - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWORD=password
    healthcheck:
      test: "pg_isready -h localhost -p 5432 -q -U postgres"
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5
    volumes:
      - pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    networks:
      - mynetwork.com

  explorer.mynetwork.com:
    image: hyperledger/explorer:latest
    container_name: explorer.mynetwork.com
    hostname: explorer.mynetwork.com
    environment:
      - DATABASE_HOST=explorerdb.mynetwork.com
      - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWD=password
      - LOG_LEVEL_APP=debug
      - LOG_LEVEL_DB=debug
      - LOG_LEVEL_CONSOLE=info
      - LOG_CONSOLE_STDOUT=true
      - DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false
      - CORE_VM_DOCKER_HOSTCONFIG_NETWORKMODE=fabric
    volumes:
      - ./config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
      - ./connection-profile:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile
      - ./crypto:/tmp/crypto
      - walletstore:/opt/wallet
    ports:
      - 8080:8080
    depends_on:
      explorerdb.mynetwork.com:
        condition: service_healthy
    networks:
      - mynetwork.com

Dear all,

I have a doubt regarding the *minimum system requirements for hyperledger explorer*. 
I am using a system with 4GB RAM and  80 GB SSD.
I am using the hyperledger explorer docker images with tag 1.1.2

*When I run the _top_ command* ,  I see a process with random name consuming 197% of CPU and 60% of memory (https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30879156/97715100-46477d80-1ac2-11eb-92a3-a121e512d81e.png)

*output of _docker stats_: *shows hyperleger explorer db service is consuming 197 % of CPU and 60% of memory (https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30879156/97715625-ebfaec80-1ac2-11eb-993c-2e5c15b391ed.png) 

I am not sure whether that random process is linked with hyperledger_explorer_db container.

If I remove the hyperledger explorer services, the random process disappears and CPU utilization and memory becomes normal . 

I initially thought my system was under DDoS Trojan attacks as specified here https://admin-ahead.com/forum/server-security-hardening/unix-trojan-ddos_xor-1-chinese-chicken-multiplatform-dos-botnets-trojan/

But now i doubt that the random process is linked with hyperledger explorer db. 

Why  hyperledger explorer db docker container is starting a random process in the host machine and consumes 190 % of CPU and 60 % memory.  ?

I would require help for the following questions :  
 
- Does anyone have experienced this behavior when using hyperledger explorer ?

- Is this a normal behaviour of hyperledger explorer db docker services to consume this much CPU and memory ? 

- What is the minimum system requirements to run hyperledger explorer docker services


Thanks & regards,
Anand

In that case, you don't need to specify/override command for Explorer container. And also need to update your connection profile which is consumed by Explorer to the new syntax. Please refer [here](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md) for the detail.

Hi @nike It seems to be kind of network issue that is reported in the following JIRA of fabric-sdk-node.
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-1646
This error is incurred sometime when multiple transaction are raced. So far this error doesn't give any major effects to Explorer.

The fix of this issue has already been introduced into the latest fabric-network package, but it's introduced another issue as below.
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-1663?jql=project%20%3D%20FABN%20AND%20text%20~%20%22system%20chaincode%22

The fix of this issue has already been introduced into the latest fabric-network package, but it's introduced another issue as below.
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-1663
So we have to wait for the next release 2.2.4.
So we have to wait for the next release 2.2.4 of fabric-network package.

I am trying to configure HyperLedger Explorer v1.1.3 (Sep 28, 2020) to point to an existing IBM Blockchain Platform (simple 1 Org network).   Does anyone in this channel has a config tips / guide to point to the IBM cloud (instead of the local test network)?     

For example, current available config doc is to point to a local fabric test network: https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer 
What I am looking for: config to point to IBM Blockchain Platform cloud ==> adjustments to config.json etc required / other tips?

Thank you.
Please refer the case that Explorer is running as a container. In this case, in your connection profile, you need to specify a peer with URL which is directly reachable from Explorer container.
https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/examples/net1/connection-profile/first-network.json
https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#run-hyperledger-explorer-using-docker-compose
Explorer requires admin privilege to query chaincode info to fabric network.
And Fabric network uses `Node OU`  to confer a role onto an identity.
This convention allows you to distinguish MSP roles by the OU present in the CommonName attribute of the X509 certificate.
This error is saying that node ou for `admin` is undefined. Please make sure that Node OU is enabled in your each `config.yaml` ex. `crypto-artifacts/**/msp/config.yaml`
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-2.2/membership/membership.html#node-ou-roles-and-msps

I remember 1.4 sdk can specify endorsing peers
I remember 1.4 sdk can specify endorsing peers. 2.2 uses discovery to find endorsing peer according to endorsing policies automatically. It may be a bug which has been already reported on JIRA.
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-1687

I see that the Explorer documentation mentions some authentication possibilities: https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/main/README-CONFIG.md

Hello! I am collaborating on the Fabric-Private-Chaincode stream and we would like to use Blockchain Explorer to easily show how transactions are stored using FPC. We would like to be able to also show the chaincode function and arguments that are sent (they should be encrypted). I am not sure where I would have to modify to add these fields. Any pointers are appreciated!

Hyperledger Explorer uses the channel subscriptions provided by fabric-node-sdk. Your data should be somewhere in the transaction data provided by the channel subscription. I'd start by checking if the rw-sets of your transactions are being synced to HL Explorer's database

thank you for replying. I did find that in the sync service blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/sync/SyncService.ts  they are obtaining the info I would like to display `chaincode_proposal_input =
					txObj.payload.data.actions[0].payload.chaincode_proposal_payload.input
						.chaincode_spec.input.args;` what I donÂ´t know is where that field should be displayed ...

I think you need to modify `client/src/components/View/TransactionView.js` and `app/persistence/fabric/CRUDService.ts`. In `CRUDService.ts`, `chaincode_proposal_input` field is currently filtered from API response.
[blockchain-explorer/CRUDService.ts at main Â· hyperledger/blockchain-explorer](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/main/app/persistence/fabric/CRUDService.ts#L49)

Hi everyone.
I noticed when I add *peer* from another organization in my network and join it to channel, it *doesn't have* installed *_lifecycle* chaincode (1*) and that's the reason why *explorer*, deployed for this organization is *failed*.
I found a workaround for it - to approve some chaincode, it could be even not being packed and installed, like 
`peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name randomchaincodename --package-id 1 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles {path_here} --cafile {path_here} --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1`. I executed it from initial peer of first organization. Somehow it forced new peer to install _livecycle chaincode (2*) and than explorer could start.

```
1*. Right after join new peer to channel on discovery request
[
	{
		"MSPID": "RG-288-853-MSP",
		"LedgerHeight": 4,
		"Endpoint": "nd-898-226-493.rg-288-853.int.chainstack.com:7051",
		"Identity": "{certificate here}",
		"Chaincodes": [
			"_lifecycle"
		]
	},
	{
		"MSPID": "RG-853-084-MSP",
		"LedgerHeight": 4,
		"Endpoint": "nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com:7051",
		"Identity": "{certificate here}",
		"Chaincodes": null   # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
	}
]

Also explorer shows next lines in logs:
[ERROR] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Synchronizer Error >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
[ERROR] Sync - { FabricError: Query failed. Errors: ["Error: Peer nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com is not running chaincode _lifecycle"]
    at SingleQueryHandler.evaluate (/opt/explorer/node_modules/fabric-network/lib/impl/query/singlequeryhandler.js:47:23)
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:68:7) name: 'FabricError' }
[INFO] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Closing client processor >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
```

```
2*. Than execute 
peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name lifecycle --package-id 1 -o orderer_address:7050 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles path_to_cert --cafile path_to_cert   --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1

and now discovery returns
[
	{
		"MSPID": "RG-288-853-MSP",
		"LedgerHeight": 5,
		"Endpoint": "nd-898-226-493.rg-288-853.int.chainstack.com:7051",
		"Identity": "{ certificate here}",
		"Chaincodes": [
			"_lifecycle"
		]
	},
	{
		"MSPID": "RG-853-084-MSP",
		"LedgerHeight": 5,
		"Endpoint": "nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com:7051",
		"Identity": "{ certificate here }",
		"Chaincodes": [
			"_lifecycle"    # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< not it's here
		]
	}
]

And explorer runs successfully.
```

For sure that way is not production ready. How to fix it and make explorer works right after deploying? I use hlf-peer 2.2.0 and hlf-explorer 1.1.4

It seems to be caused by insufficient privilege of identity you specified in connection profile. There are 2 options. Recently we changed it the code around this implementation. So if you use the latest codebase and build your own image on your local, it'll be resolved. The other one is to wait for the next release which is scheduled this weekend.
`./build_docker_image.sh` will generate new images (explorer / explorer-db)

I Think your problem is in the docker-compose.yaml file, specifically in this section```volumes:
      - /"REAL PATH TO THE FILE"/blockchain-explorer/config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
      - /"REAL PATH TO THE DIRECTORY"/blockchain-explorer/connection-profile:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile
      - /"REAL PATH TO THE DIRECTORY"/fabric-samples/test-network/organizations:/tmp/crypto
      - walletstore:/opt/explorer/wallet``````
In my case I replaced REAL PATH with ```/Users/xxx/go/src/github.com/hyperledger-labs/fabric-private-chaincode/samples/deployment/test-network```
```

      - /"REAL PATH TO THE FILE"/blockchain-explorer/config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
      - /"REAL PATH TO THE DIRECTORY"/blockchain-explorer/connection-profile:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile
      - /"REAL PATH TO THE DIRECTORY"/fabric-samples/test-network/organizations:/tmp/crypto
      - walletstore:/opt/explorer/wallet``````
In my case I replaced REAL PATH with ```/Users/xxx/go/src/github.com/hyperledger-labs/fabric-private-chaincode/samples/deployment/test-network```

msg:
That's my docker-compose.yaml file:

# SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
version: '2.1'

volumes:
  pgdata:
  walletstore:

networks:
  mynetwork.com:
   # external:
      name: test-network

services:

  explorerdb.mynetwork.com:
    image: hyperledger/explorer-db:latest
    container_name: explorerdb.mynetwork.com
    hostname: explorerdb.mynetwork.com
    environment:
      - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWORD=password
    healthcheck:
      test: "pg_isready -h localhost -p 5432 -q -U postgres"
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5
    volumes:
      - pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    networks:
      - mynetwork.com

  explorer.mynetwork.com:
    image: hyperledger/explorer:latest
    container_name: explorer.mynetwork.com
    hostname: explorer.mynetwork.com
    environment:
      - DATABASE_HOST=explorerdb.mynetwork.com
      - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWD=password
      - LOG_LEVEL_APP=debug
      - LOG_LEVEL_DB=debug
      - LOG_LEVEL_CONSOLE=info
      - LOG_CONSOLE_STDOUT=true
      - DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false
    volumes:
      - ./config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
      - ./connection-profile:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile
      - /crypto-config:/tmp/crypto
      - walletstore:/opt/explorer/wallet
    ports:
      - 8080:8080
    depends_on:
      explorerdb.mynetwork.com:
        condition: service_healthy
    networks:
      - mynetwork.com

In your `connection-profile.json`, you have configured incorrect path for adminPrivateKey. You need to specify valid path on the `explorer` container which start with `/tmp/crypto/...`, not on host machine which start with `/home/gavimat/...`.

In your `connection-profile.json`, you have configured incorrect path for adminPrivateKey, signedCert and tlsCACerts. You need to specify valid path on the `explorer` container which start with `/tmp/crypto/...`, not on host machine which start with `/home/gavimat/...`.
